contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox MLB player |name=Gus Polidor |position=[[Infielder]] |bats=Right |throws=Right |birth_date={{Birth date|1961|10|26}} |birth_place=[[Caracas]], [[Venezuela]] |death_date={{death date and age|1995|4|28|1961|10|26}} |death_place=[[Caracas]], [[Venezuela]] |debutdate=September 7 |debutyear=1985 |debutteam=[[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim|California Angels]] |finaldate=July 22 |finalyear=1993 |finalteam=[[Florida Marlins]] |stat1label=[[Batting average]] |stat1value=.207 |stat2label=[[Home run]]s |stat2value=2 |stat3label=[[Runs batted in]] |stat3value=35 |teams=<nowiki></nowiki> * [[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim|California Angels]] ({{By|1985}}-{{By|1988}}) * [[Milwaukee Brewers]] ({{By|1989}}-{{By|1990}}) * [[Florida Marlins]] ({{By|1993}}) }} '''Gustavo Adolfo Polidor González''' [poh-lee-DOR], (October 26, 1961 – April 28, 1995), was a [[shortstop]] in [[Major League Baseball]] who played for the [[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim|California Angels]] (1985–88), [[Milwaukee Brewers]] (1989–90) and [[Florida Marlins]] (1993). He was born in [[Caracas]], [[Venezuela]]. His best year was 1987 with the Angels, when he hit for a .263 [[batting average]], with 2 [[home run|homers]] and 15 [[Run batted in|RBI]] in 137 [[at bats]]. After dropping off to .148 in 1988 he was traded to the Brewers. Polidor played in a career-high 79 games in 1989 and was later a member of the Marlins in their 1993 inaugural season. In his major league career, Polidor batted .207, with 2 home runs, 35 [[runs batted in]], 33 [[Run (baseball statistics)|runs scored]], 15 [[double (baseball)|doubles]] and 3 [[stolen base]]s. Polidor made a brief comeback attempt as a [[replacement player]] with the [[Montreal Expos]] in spring training of 1995. Less than a month later, he was murdered in Caracas as he tried to protect his son from two men who were trying to steal his car.<ref>[http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_MURAAAAIBAJ&sjid=c-wDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3612,6701246&dq=gus+polidor+murder&hl=en Former Marlin killed]</ref> He was only 33 years old. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Baseballstats|br=p/polidgu01|fangraphs=1010420|cube=gus-polidor}} *[http://web.archive.org/web/20041029084958/http://www.geocities.com/Colosseum/Park/2262/ History of Venezuelan ''MLB'' Players page] {{Authority control|VIAF=31324859}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]] --> | NAME =Polidor, Gus | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Baseball player | DATE OF BIRTH =October 26, 1961 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Caracas]], [[Venezuela]] | DATE OF DEATH =April 28, 1995 | PLACE OF DEATH =[[Caracas]], [[Venezuela]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Polidor, Gus}} [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:1995 deaths]] [[Category:California Angels players]] [[Category:Caribbean Series players]] [[Category:Denver Zephyrs players]] [[Category:Edmonton Trappers players]] [[Category:Florida Marlins players]] [[Category:Holyoke Millers players]] [[Category:Major League Baseball players from Venezuela]] [[Category:Major League Baseball replacement players]] [[Category:Major League Baseball shortstops]] [[Category:Milwaukee Brewers players]] [[Category:Murdered sportspeople]] [[Category:Nashua Angels players]] [[Category:People from Caracas]] [[Category:People murdered in Venezuela]] [[Category:Tacoma Tigers players]] [[Category:Venezuelan murder victims]] [[Category:Waterbury Angels players]] {{Venezuela-baseball-infielder-stub}}
